captions.text: [SCREECHING TIRES]

CHRIS HARRIS: This is the brief
story of our trip to

visit Pagani and drive
the Huayra.

These are crazy smash-and-grab
raids, really.

Shoot what you can, live for the
moment, and a part of me
exists purely for this.
[AIRPORT NOISES]

CHRIS HARRIS: We just
landed in Bologna.

And the baggage carousel isn't
even whirring yet.

And I think there's only
one plane landed.

So in fact it's right beside
the terminal building.

So I'm just wondering where our
bags are with 200 other

people, having just been thrown
around like a rag doll
on BA 666 from Gatwick.

Pleasant way to travel,
but I'm excited
because you know what?

I'm coming to Italy, coming
to [INAUDIBLE]

Valley in Bologna, driving
to LeMans.
That's always special.

I've not been here for a long
time, largely because Ferrari
doesn't run anymore.
But that's another story.

So why is it, whenever you book
a hired car, you always

book the one with
a massive queue.
And then look, there's Sixt.

There's about four others
down there.

Is there someone out there to
check the car over before?
HERTZ EMPLOYEE: No.

But there are some
marks on it.

If you find other marks
just contact us.
About those, don't worry.

CHRIS HARRIS: We didn't get sat
nav because my credit card
would have bounced.

And being Italian, he told me
that he wouldn't charge me if

there were only small scratches
on the car, which
means he will charge me.

Rental car bingo-- so we don't
know what we're going to get.

I ticked the box for the
cheapest, cheapest car, of
course, as you do.

So I'm thinking Fiat Panda,
would you reckon?
No?
Fiat Panda?

MALE SPEAKER (OFFSCREEN):
Yeah, that
sounds like a good shot.

Maybe we could squeeze all of
our kit and that in the 500.
CHRIS HARRIS: OK.
Where is Hertz?

MALE SPEAKER (OFFSCREEN):
Blip the key.
CHRIS HARRIS: Hertz.
Hertz.
There she is.
Panda.
Some marks on it?
Fucking hell.
[LAUGHTER]

CHRIS HARRIS: He described it
as some small marks, and it
needs reshelling.
[LAUGHTER]

CHRIS HARRIS: What else
is wrong with it?
Look at this.

This is why this country's
brilliant.

I just went in there and said,
look, the hired car's

completely knackered, and
it's got massive damage.
So I wrote, big damage.

And the guy just said, yeah,
don't worry about it.

From the airport, it's a
20-minute wobble in the

shacked Fiat, then dinner with
the chap who has the fastest
name in the world--
Luca Venturi, Pagani's PR man.

And wouldn't you know it, as we
discussed aerodynamics and

weight distribution over steak
and balsamic vinegar, test
driver Davide Testi--

a man with another very,
very quick name--
pops by on his way home.

The owner of the restaurant
immediately absconds from his

duties for a photo
with the car.

In fact, everyone photographs
this remarkable-looking
machine, including me.

And then Davide leaves
as only an Italian
test driver can leave.
[PUNCHES THE GAS]

CHRIS HARRIS: Next morning, it's
off to the Pagani factory

and an introduction from the man
himself, Horacio Pagani,

who always talks about his
creations with the zeal and

passion of a father displaying
his newborn child.

Better still, the tall bloke to
the right is Ola Kallenius,

the boss of AMG, which builds
the Huayra's twin-turbo V12.

He was in town to experience
the car for the first time.
OLA KALLENIUS: Zonda's good.
This is better.

But I have to look at the fine
print of my contract.
[LAUGHING]

CHRIS HARRIS: But there's only
so much talking you can do in

the presence of a
car like this.

First, you want to be on your
own with it, to drink in that

shape and those incredible
dished rear wheels.

And then, you have to just
go and drive it.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[ENGINE REVVING]

CHRIS HARRIS: So finally,
I'm driving the Huayra.

That's the first
point to make.

It's called the "Why-Rah," not
the "Why-Ar-Uh" or the

"Why-ee-Rah" or the "Hee-Ar-Uh."
It's Huayra.

One day I'll learn to
say it properly.

Mr. Pagani probably doesn't like
the way I say it, but I'm

trying, OK, Horacio,
I'm trying.

What do I think about
this car?

Rather predictably,
it's not like
anything else I've driven.

I'm now on quite a bumpy, quite
open A road in Italy.

I've got quite supple
suspension.

I've got a gearbox that's
running in automatic mode.

And actually, even though I've
got seven gears, because of

the torque on offer, I need
about three gears.

This is a car that
is easy to drive.
That's the first point.
It's easy to drive.
Why is it easy to drive?
Well, there's so much torque--
1,000 Newton-meters.
Get that?

That's 737 foot-pounds of torque
in a car that weights
1,350 kilograms dry.
That's outrageous.

And it means that you just
squeeze the throttle.

The boost builds at around 2,000
rpm, and you don't have
to think about it.

Pedal weights are quite heavy,
obviously only two pedals.

But for me, one of the reasons
why this car is easy to drive
is the steering.

It's very, very accurate, and
it's very precise, and it's
got a good amount of feel.

And that means that you
can place the car.

And these massive hypercars,
you've got to be confident

that you're not just going to
take the sides off to be able

to drive it properly
on the road.
So that's what I've got.

I've got a car that is perfectly
relaxing to drive.
It rides well enough.
The cabin is big and airy.

And whereas an Aventador is kind
of up and at you and you

feel like you're stuck in
between, wedged in between

great big amounts of face sheer
and center console, this
is big and open.

My knee can move in front
of the center console.

And of course, the quality of
the cabin and the jewelry

that's going on here
is just staggering.
You know that.

I'm going to have a look at that
now because we need to

celebrate the details
on this car.

Carbon, polished metal, and
leather meet in one great,
writhing lump of loveliness.
The clock faces are illegible.

But the central readout is
electronic and clear.

The wheel is nearly perfect
in shape and size.
The pedals feel good.

But the stumpy gear lever
is almost too
cool not to use itself.

The signature quad exhausts are
in pure titanium, and the

system weighs just
12 kilograms.

Suspension is identical to the
Zonda R, which lapped the ring
in six minutes and 47 seconds.

The car has around 730
horsepower from a six-liter,
twin-turbo V12 by AMG.

It's a bespoke engine
for Pagani.

And it has its own internal
code-- for
geeks like me, M158--
like that.

It's a massively impressive
power plant.

And of course, that's the
brilliance of Pagani.

Rather than going out and trying
to do his own engine,

he's using something that he
knows works from a company

that has kind of unprecedented
skill at making massive
horsepower.

So the AMG power plant is
crucial to this package.

Perhaps the key issue around
the Huayra is the noise, or

rather lack of it, or
rather presence of
turbocharged noise.

Being turbocharged, this car
just cannot sound like those

amazing Zondas we had before,
particularly that last R

version, which just sounded like
all sorts of bad things
going wrong in the right way.

So we have turbo noise
this time.
Here, I'll give you some.
Get a load of this.
[ENGINE NOISE]

CHRIS HARRIS: Interestingly,
Pagani has worked hard to try
and tune that noise.

It's the first turbocharged car
that I've driven that has

got deliberately tuned
turbocharged noise.

And there's wastegate
rattles and fizzles.
And there's lots going on.

Does it sound as
good as Zonda?
No.

It's a different noise and one
that I think over time could
become quite special.

So to turn the Huayra into
something that is actually not

that friendly and is a full-on
supercar, hypercar experience,

there's a button here
that says ESC.

You get it in sport mode, and
you hold it down for 5

seconds, and you hear
a little BINK.

And you look at the dashboard,
and it says ESC Off.

And you get a little squiggle
sign on there.
And now you're on your own.

So, second gear coming
up this rather narrow
mountain pass of a road.
Front end is great.
But the performance is nuts.
Oh, yes, Ha!
Ha!
Front is really good.

So we've got no understeer
really, but coming out--
it's spooling up everywhere.
It's just nuts.

Steering's a bit slow for
these sorts of roads.

As you can see, I have
to work quite hard.
It's an animal, guys.
It's an absolute animal.
Woohoohoohoo!
Woohoohoohoo!
What a machine.

I mean, the fact that it's
two-wheel drive as well.

So yeah, the billionaire can
drive it in automatic mode.

But I'll tell you what, if
you want to be a hooligan
woohoohoohoo!
What a machine.
I can't say too much.

I'm just going to concentrate
on driving it.
God, it's fast.

Does it feel like
730 horsepower?
It feels like more to me.

When the boost comes,
it's furious.
And you just hang on.
You really do.
It's fast.
It's fast.

And there's flaps going off and
there's all sorts of drama
and theater.
This is just pure hypercar.

And anyone that thinks that
Pagani's gone soft needs to
come and sit in this now.

Because this is power to weight
ratio through two
driven wheels with--
wait for it--
no traction control.
It's a tonic.

I need to back away
for a minute,
because that's so full-on.

You want to match that, you've
got to buy yourself a needle

with some brown stuff in
it because that is just
remarkable.
Is that legal?

I'm sure it is, but
Jesus Christ.

730 horsepower, two wheels,
no traction control.
Horacio, I salute you.

I needed time to cool my oil
temperature after that.
And here's the nitty-gritty.
Yes, the steering is great.

But so is the damping with the
manually adjustable Ohlins
shocks set to pretty soft.

The ceramic breaks have decent
feel and earn their keep.

Pedal lift is pretty
high though.

The seven-speed extract
gearbox is a peach--

fast and enjoyable in manual
mode, yet weighs just 96

kilograms and is mounted
transversely.

The powertrain package is neater
than the Zonda, so the

weight distribution is
a perfect 50/50.

And as for the active
aerodynamics, I didn't go fast
enough to test them.

But who cares when they
look so damn cool?

When I first saw the Huayra, I
wasn't entirely convinced.

Because I didn't think the
styling was quite as cute as

the Zonda, and I was worried
about this twin
turbocharging aspect.

Now that I've driven the car, I
have to say I got it wrong.
Do you know what?

In the flesh, when you park it
next to a Zonda, it just looks
more modern.
It just looks more appealing.
It just looks cleverer.

And I've never seen a car that's
had so much detail
lavished on it.

It's extraordinary, truly
extraordinary.

But they haven't forgotten about
the driving experience.

Because this is a
very clever car.

And I hadn't quite expected
the breadth of talent.

You can leave all the
buttons in place.

And you can leave
it in automatic.
And it's entirely usable.

OK, It's not a Nissan Micra,
but as long as you've got a

modicum of talent, you won't
have a problem mooching around
in this car, as I explained.

But if you turn the systems off,
I can't think of another
car like this--
730 BHP.

And even bigger torque figure,
two-wheel drive, and
you're on your own.

It's an animal, as
you can see.

I was sweating away, genuinely
enjoying myself.
What is this car?

I suppose it is the definitive
hypercar.

Because it's that
style statement.

It's that aesthetic statement,
mixed in with an unforgettable
driving experience.
Yeah, love it.
[ENGINE ROARING]

title: Pagani Huayra: Test Drive in Italy - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.author: ReDPoiSoN22

comments.text: BA 666? Illuminati confirmed﻿
comments.author: Christian Gather

comments.text:
His face on this video shows why this is my favorite hypercar. The Pagani 
Huarya is just a drivers car. And its an celebration of timeless relation 
between man and his car. This car looks absolutely gorgeous. Where Ferrari, 
Mclaren, and Porsche and forgotten to give the driver MORE in their 
interiors. Mr. Pagani realized that the interior is the other half of the 
equation. That leather looks and feels absolutely amazing. The naked carbon 
fiber lets you know its all about speed. The brushed aluminum shows insane 
attention to detail and an mad obsession. Then there's the driving 
characteristics and design. Driving this car like Chris did makes you a man 
lol. You can see his eyes buck out. He is on his absolute full awareness 
mode. Its not a car you can fool around in without being hyper aware of 
what's going on with the suspension. Once you turn everything off, you get 
to feel the roller coaster ride that is the Huarya. And the looks are just 
what makes this car so grand. Where as Lamborghini and Ferrari have gotten 
stuck in a endless design cycle, Pagani has its own road to carve. With no 
parent corporation telling him how and what his creation should do. Whether 
his company sinks or swims is entirely on how good his products are and the 
buyers desires. And i can honestly say i dont see how ANYONE could NOT want 
a hypercar like this. Its special, because its not just another hypercar. 
Its THE hypercar that definitely will age well.﻿
comments.author: MrSupersaiyangoku

comments.text:
For me, there are two real contenders for the most beautiful car in the 
world - this and the La Ferrari. I'm not sure which one I want most. They 
do take completely opposite, diametrically opposed approaches to many 
things, yet they're both beautiful. And fast. Fortunately, it's not a 
decision I have to make.﻿

comments.author: TheeSlyPIE

comments.text:
There's something really quite magical about the Huayra. It may not be as 
pretty as old supercars from days gone by like the 250GT Lusso, 275GTB, 
E-Type Series 1, DB4 GT etc but it has a thousand times more character than 
a P1 or LaFerrari. 

Whether it's the hand made, bespoke nature of the Huayra or incredible 
interior or the cacophony of devilish, industrial sounds emanating from the 
tail pipes, there's just so much personality to it.

To know that this car is the culmination of one man's dream and a small 
factory out of Modena is incredible.﻿
comments.author: James B

comments.text:
"Needle with brown stuff in it"
Yeah fuck that. Having been down that road I can unequivocally say it's 
nothing like driving a great car, it's fucking horrible and life 
destroying.  I know it was just used as a turn of phrase but surely given a 
guy does this for a living, he can think of something better to say?
Hate that Ive been " that guy" here , really do but had to say something. 
Not that I expect a comment made by some random guy on YouTube to even 
reach the people that matter, let alone have them care about it, especially 
on a 2 , nearly 3 year old video.
Car is amazing though and enjoyed the review apart from that one tiny 
thing.﻿

What I have in my garage is my concern not yours. Also it's my opinion

But maybe being an american all you heard about European cars are about

comments.author: Ovi Muresan

comments.text:
2 Fiat 500s and 3 new VW Golfs dont make you a bad ass sir. And though I'm 
joking, and 100% that's not what you're bragging about, the fact that 
you're bragging as a way of trying to prove your opinion has more worth 
than someone else's shows your opinion worth next to nothing. Besides, you 
misunderstood his post entirely and instead used it as a springboard to 
berate him and promote your own perceived self worth. All he tried to say 
was Americans have the ability to build cars that can compete with any 
other car on the planet. Everyone has an opinion whose are best, and often 
times that boils down to patriotism, but demeaning a fellow auto enthusiast 
based on where he's from makes you an ass.
comments.author: Joseph Hudson

comments.text:
+Prashanth Panicker You have no idea what u are talking about man, sorry... 
Comparing american BS american cars even Corvette (the pride) with any

korean or japanese cars (maybe taxis), sorry no offense... I know u will

comments.author: Ovi Muresan

comments.text:
Whoops, my mistake. Sorry about that.

Don't be so quick to knock the Americans based on the past. I can see how a 
6.2 L supercharged pushrod V8 making only 650 horsepower can seem crude but 
once you look further into the specs there is some really cool engineering 
going on. Pushrods mean the engine is crazy light for an engine of this 
size. I can't find figures so don't take this to heart but apparently it is 
lighter than the Ferrari v8. Cylinder deactivation makes for incredible gas 
mileage for such a big motor and the z06's price point is nothing short of 
incredible. All things considered I can never decide if I like the Corvette 
v8 or the 458 v8 more but they are both certainly automotive greats.
comments.author: Prashanth Panicker

comments.text:
+Prashanth Panicker  you didn't get my comment i was standing by the 
italian motors not the german but i respect both but american motors nah 
pass
comments.author: Kamal el debieky

comments.text:
+Kamal el debieky Not quite. I would have agreed with you a few years ago 
when BMW was putting a 500 horsepower V10 in the e60 M5 and Mercedes was 
making wicked Naturally Aspirated V8s but right now the title seems to go 
to the Italians or Americans. It's dissapointing that the AMG 6.0 Liter 
Turbo v12 makes roughly the same amount of power as Ferrari F12's natural 
aspirated 6.2 v12. I know there is more to a car than power and no Ferrari 
will compare to a Huayra but I do hope that the AMG v12 is underrated like 
most German motors.
comments.author: Prashanth Panicker

comments.text: +Joseph Hudson supercar*** not supercharged
comments.author: Joseph Hudson

comments.text:
+Dance1617 I'm no car manufacturer, but I'd imagine a majority of R&D of 
any car goes into the engine, and since AMG specialized in these powerful, 
specialty engines it makes sense for Pagani to focus their energy on the 
emotional aspect of a car (design, aesthetics, etc) because that's what 
ultimately many supercharged buyers end up with as a differentiating 
factor. They could have a Bugatti (but they're rather bulky) or a 
Lamborghini (but they're rather outlandish), so instead they settle in the 
middle on this beautiful piece with a proven manufacturer building an 
incredible engine, and they get the best of both world. It's a win-win.
comments.author: Joseph Hudson

comments.text:
+patrick rose doesn't another company already use them? This market is 
about exclusivity you don't want to share any character with anyone else at 
this price range.

+Neil McMahon "Because they are made out of plastic."  The new Corvette is 
less than 10% plastic, which is better than almost any other car.  
Obviously when you're talking about normal hatchbacks, etc. they're full of 
plastics, some more equal than others, but the new Focus, along with all 
other Focuses, drives a lot better than all of its rivals, and the interior 
was never made out of the bits of the Lego reject bin, and the cars that 
were are all gone and replaced (the Mustang, CTS, Corvette, Impala, 200C, 
you get the picture.)
"If everyone has one, then they are not considered special."  No shit 
Sherlock.  That's what (partly) makes hypercars so expensive.
comments.author: Alex Heed (Drive Clubber)

comments.text:
+Alex Heed because they are made out of plastic and if everybody has one, 
then they are not considered special.
comments.author: Neil McMahon

comments.text:

(Porsche 918) and Japan doesn't even have one.  Plus we're busy building 
more cars you'd be able to afford if you weren't a homeless drug addict.

comments.text:
If money was not an issue I would have a Bentley Continental GT V8 S daily 
driver and a Pagani Huayra for the weekends.

The Bentley might just happen in the next few years but the Huayra can't be 
had with an honest normal job. 

You basically have to be wealthy, not rich. You can mostly only become 
wealthy from others working for you or doing some sort of high profile 
business and dedicating your life to it.

I started on that path but when I realized it consumes your entire life and 
friends and family get left behind and out, I changed my mind.﻿
